Diffusion State-Guided Projected Gradient for Inverse Problems

Rayhan Zirvi
Computing and Mathematical Sciences
California Institute of Technology
rayhanzirvi@caltech.edu
&Bahareh Tolooshamsâˆ—
Computing and Mathematical Sciences
California Institute of Technology
btoloosh@caltech.edu
\ANDAnima Anandkumar
Computing and Mathematical Sciences
California Institute of Technology
anima@caltech.edu
Equal contribution
Abstract

Recent advancements in diffusion models have been effective in learning data priors for solving inverse problems. They leverage diffusion sampling steps for inducing a data prior while using a measurement guidance gradient at each step to impose data consistency. For general inverse problems, approximations are needed when an unconditionally trained diffusion model is used since the measurement likelihood is intractable, leading to inaccurate posterior sampling. In other words, due to their approximations, these methods fail to preserve the generation process on the data manifold defined by the diffusion prior, leading to artifacts in applications such as image restoration. To enhance the performance and robustness of diffusion models in solving inverse problems, we propose Diffusion State-Guided Projected Gradient (DiffStateGrad), which projects the measurement gradient onto a subspace that is a low-rank approximation of an intermediate state of the diffusion process. DiffStateGrad, as a module, can be added to a wide range of diffusion-based inverse solvers to improve the preservation of the diffusion process on the prior manifold and filter out artifact-inducing components. We highlight that DiffStateGrad improves the robustness of diffusion models in terms of the choice of measurement guidance step size and noise while improving the worst-case performance. Finally, we demonstrate that DiffStateGrad improves upon the state-of-the-art on linear and nonlinear image restoration inverse problems.

1 Introduction

Inverse problems are ubiquitous in science and engineering, playing a crucial role in simulation-based scientific discovery and real-world applicationsÂ (Groetsch & Groetsch, 1993). They arise in fields such as medical imaging, remote sensing, astrophysics, computational neuroscience, molecular dynamics simulations, systems biology, and generally solving partial differential equations (PDEs). Inverse problems aim to recover an unknown signal ğ’™â‹†âˆˆâ„nsuperscriptğ’™â‹†superscriptâ„ğ‘›{\bm{x}}^{\star}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹† end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT from noisy observations

Inverse problems are ill-posed, i.e., in the absence of a structure governing the underlying desired signal ğ’™ğ’™{\bm{x}}bold_italic_x, many solutions can explain the measurements ğ’šğ’š{\bm{y}}bold_italic_y. In the Bayesian framework, this structure is translated into a prior pâ¢(ğ’™)ğ‘ğ’™p({\bm{x}})italic_p ( bold_italic_x ), which can be combined with the likelihood term pâ¢(ğ’š|ğ’™)ğ‘conditionalğ’šğ’™p({\bm{y}}|{\bm{x}})italic_p ( bold_italic_y | bold_italic_x ) to define a posterior distribution pâ¢(ğ’™|ğ’š)âˆpâ¢(ğ’š|ğ’™)â¢pâ¢(ğ’™)proportional-toğ‘conditionalğ’™ğ’šğ‘conditionalğ’šğ’™ğ‘ğ’™p({\bm{x}}|{\bm{y}})\propto p({\bm{y}}|{\bm{x}})p({\bm{x}})italic_p ( bold_italic_x | bold_italic_y ) âˆ italic_p ( bold_italic_y | bold_italic_x ) italic_p ( bold_italic_x ). Hence, solving the inverse problem translates into performing a Maximum a Posteriori (MAP) estimation or drawing high-probability samples from the posteriorÂ (Stuart, 2010). Given the forward model pâ¢(ğ’š|ğ’™)ğ‘conditionalğ’šğ’™p({\bm{y}}|{\bm{x}})italic_p ( bold_italic_y | bold_italic_x ), the critical step is to choose the prior pâ¢(ğ’™)ğ‘ğ’™p({\bm{x}})italic_p ( bold_italic_x ), which is often challenging; one needs domain knowledge to define a prior or a large amount of data to learn it.

Prior works consider sparse priors and provide a theoretical analysis of conditions for the unique recovery of data, a problem known as compressed sensingÂ (Donoho, 2006; CandÃ¨s etÂ al., 2006). Sparse priors have shown usefulness in medical imagingÂ (Lustig etÂ al., 2007), computational neuroscienceÂ (Olshausen & Field, 1997), and engineering applications. This approach is categorized into model-based priors where a structure is assumed on the signal instead of being learned.

Recent literature goes beyond such model-based priors and leverages information from data. The latest works employ generative diffusion modelsÂ (Song & Ermon, 2019; Kadkhodaie & Simoncelli, 2021), which implicitly learn the data prior pâ¢(ğ’™)ğ‘ğ’™p({\bm{x}})italic_p ( bold_italic_x ) by learning a process that transforms noise into samples from a complex data distribution. For inverse problems, this reverse generation process is guided by the likelihood pâ¢(ğ’š|ğ’™)ğ‘conditionalğ’šğ’™p({\bm{y}}|{\bm{x}})italic_p ( bold_italic_y | bold_italic_x ), forming a denoiser posterior, to generate data-consistent samples. While diffusion models show state-of-the-art performance, they still face challenges in solving inverse problems.

The main challenge arises since the denoiser posterior, specifically the likelihood component pâ¢(ğ’š|ğ’™)ğ‘conditionalğ’šğ’™p({\bm{y}}|{\bm{x}})italic_p ( bold_italic_y | bold_italic_x ), is intractable since the diffusion is trained unconditionallyÂ (Song etÂ al., 2021). Prior work addresses this challenge by proposing various approximations or projections to the gradient related to the measurement likelihood pâ¢(ğ’š|ğ’™)ğ‘conditionalğ’šğ’™p({\bm{y}}|{\bm{x}})italic_p ( bold_italic_y | bold_italic_x ) to achieve likely solutionsÂ (Kawar etÂ al., 2022); when these approximations are not valid, it results in inaccurate posterior sampling and the introduction of â€œartifactsâ€ in the reconstructed dataÂ (Chung etÂ al., 2023). Latent diffusion models (LDMs)Â (Rombach etÂ al., 2022), due to the nonlinearity of the latent-to-pixel decoder, further exacerbate this challenge. Besides this approximation, the lack of robustness of diffusion models to the measurement gradient step sizeÂ (Peng etÂ al., 2024) and the measurement noise, and the lack of guarantees for worst-case performance limits their practical applications for inverse problems.

Our contributions: We propose a Diffusion State-Guided Projected Gradient (DiffStateGrad) to address the challenge of staying on the data manifold in solving inverse problems. We focus on gradient-based measurement guidance approaches that use the measurement as guidance to move the intermediate diffusion state ğ’™tsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡{\bm{x}}_{t}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT toward high-probability regions of the posterior. DiffStateGrad projects the measurement guidance gradient onto a low-rank subspace, capturing the learned prior at time tğ‘¡titalic_t in the diffusion process (FigureÂ 1). We visualize how the diffusion process is pushed off the manifold when the measurement step size is relatively large in a diffusion model and how the incorporation of DiffStateGrad alleviates this challenge (FigureÂ 2). We perform singular value decomposition (SVD) on the intermediate diffusion state of an image and use the rğ‘Ÿritalic_r highest contributing singular vectors as a choice of our projection matrix; by projecting the measurement gradient onto our proposed subspace, we aim to remove the directions orthogonal to the local manifold structure.

    We show that the crucial factor is the choice of the subspace, not the low-rank nature of the subspace projection. We find that our DiffStateGrad projection enhances performance, in contrast to random subspace projections and low-rank approximations of the measurement gradient (TableÂ 1).

  • â€¢

    We theoretically prove how DiffStateGrad helps the samples remain on or close to the manifold, hence improving reconstruction quality (PropositionÂ 1).

DiffStateGrad consistently shows lower standard deviation across the test datasets than state-of-the-art methods.

Our experiments cover a wide range of linear inverse problems of box inpainting, random inpainting, Gaussian deblur, motion deblur, and super-resolution (TablesÂ 2, 3 andÂ 5) and nonlinear inverse problems of phase retrieval, nonlinear deblur, and high dynamic range (HDR) (TableÂ 4) for image restoration tasks.

2 Background & Related Works

Learning-based priors.â€ƒThese methods leverage data structures captured by a pre-trained denoiserÂ (Romano etÂ al., 2017) as plug-and-play priorsÂ (Venkatakrishnan etÂ al., 2013), or deep generative models such as variational autoencoders (VAEs) Â (Kingma, 2013) and generative adversarial networks (GANs)Â (Goodfellow etÂ al., 2014) to solve inverse problemsÂ (Bora etÂ al., 2017; Ulyanov etÂ al., 2018). The state-of-the-art is based on generative diffusion models, which have shown promising performance in generating high-quality samples in computer vision (Song etÂ al., 2023b), solving PDEsÂ (Shu etÂ al., 2023), and high-energy physicsÂ (Shmakov etÂ al., 2024).

Using a latent diffusion model introduces an additional complexity to solving inverse problems. The challenge arises from the nonlinear nature and non-uniqueness mapping of the encoder/decoder, discussed byÂ Rout etÂ al. (2023) in their proposed Posterior Sampling with Latent Diffusion (PSLD); PSLD improves performance by enforcing fixed-point properties on the representations.

Diffusion-based inverse problems addressing challenges of intractable denoiser posterior.â€ƒTo address the intractability of the gradient for the reverse diffusion, Diffusion Posterior Sampling (DPS)Â (Chung etÂ al., 2023), approximates the probability pâ¢(ğ’šâˆ£ğ’™t)â‰ˆpâ¢(ğ’š|ğ’™^0â‰”ğ”¼â¢[ğ’™0âˆ£ğ’™t])ğ‘conditionalğ’šsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡ğ‘â‰”conditionalğ’šsubscript^ğ’™0ğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalsubscriptğ’™0subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡p({\bm{y}}\mid{\bm{x}}_{t})\approx p({\bm{y}}|\hat{{\bm{x}}}_{0}\coloneqq% \mathbb{E}[{\bm{x}}_{0}\mid{\bm{x}}_{t}])italic_p ( bold_italic_y âˆ£ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰ˆ italic_p ( bold_italic_y | over^ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰” blackboard_E [ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ£ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ) using the conditional expectation of the data. Extending to the latent case, Latent-DPS uses pâ¢(ğ’š|ğ’›t)â‰ˆpâ¢(ğ’š|ğ’™^0:=ğ’Ÿâ¢(ğ”¼â¢[ğ’›0|ğ’›t]))ğ‘conditionalğ’šsubscriptğ’›ğ‘¡ğ‘assignconditionalğ’šsubscript^ğ’™0ğ’Ÿğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalsubscriptğ’›0subscriptğ’›ğ‘¡p({\bm{y}}|{\bm{z}}_{t})\approx p({\bm{y}}|\hat{{\bm{x}}}_{0}:=\mathcal{D}(% \mathbb{E}[{\bm{z}}_{0}|{\bm{z}}_{t}]))italic_p ( bold_italic_y | bold_italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰ˆ italic_p ( bold_italic_y | over^ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := caligraphic_D ( blackboard_E [ bold_italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | bold_italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ) )Â (Song etÂ al., 2023a). Two intuitive drawbacks of this approach are that a) the image estimate ğ’™^0subscript^ğ’™0\hat{{\bm{x}}}_{0}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is reconstructed using an expectation, which results in inaccurate estimations for multi-modal complex distributions, and b) the measurement gradient directly updates the noisy state ğ’™tsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡{\bm{x}}_{t}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which may push away the state from the desired noise level at tğ‘¡titalic_t.

Prior works aim to address the first challenge by going beyond first-order statisticsÂ (Rout etÂ al., 2024) or incorporating posterior covariance into the maximum likelihood estimation stepÂ (Peng etÂ al., 2024). Other lines of work address the second issue by decoupling the measurement guidance from the sampling process; they update the data estimate ğ’™^0subscript^ğ’™0\hat{{\bm{x}}}_{0}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT at time tğ‘¡titalic_t using the measurement gradient before resampling it to the noisy manifoldÂ (Song etÂ al., 2023a; Zhang etÂ al., 2024). The above-discussed approaches are still highly sensitive to the measurement gradient step sizeÂ (Peng etÂ al., 2024). Indeed, balancing the measurement gradient with the unconditional score function remains a significant challenge to solving inverse problems using measurement-guided generation. Wu etÂ al. (2024) avoids the discussed approximations and samples from the posterior directly to resolve the need to find a balance between measurement guidance and the prior process.

Projections in diffusion models.â€ƒManifold and subspace projections are used in various contexts in diffusion models. He etÂ al. (2024) uses a manifold-preserving approach to improve the efficiency of diffusion generation. Chung etÂ al. (2022) proposes a manifold constraint to project the measurement gradient into the data manifold ğ’™0subscriptğ’™0{\bm{x}}_{0}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT; our proposal is more effective, which projects the measurement gradient on the noisy diffusion state related to ğ’™tsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡{\bm{x}}_{t}bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or ğ’›tsubscriptğ’›ğ‘¡{\bm{z}}_{t}bold_italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to stay close to â„³tsubscriptâ„³ğ‘¡\mathcal{M}_{t}caligraphic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT rather than â„³0subscriptâ„³0\mathcal{M}_{0}caligraphic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Conditional diffusion models for inverse problems.â€ƒWe focus on unconditional diffusion models as learned priors to solve general inverse problems. This approach leverages already trained diffusion models, which is useful for domains with abundant data. Another approach is to train conditional diffusion models where âˆ‡ğ’™tlogâ¡ptâ¢(ğ’šâˆ£ğ’™t)subscriptâˆ‡subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘ğ‘¡conditionalğ’šsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡\nabla_{{\bm{x}}_{t}}\log p_{t}({\bm{y}}\mid{\bm{x}}_{t})âˆ‡ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_y âˆ£ bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is directly captured by the score function, or where the diffusion directly transforms the measurement into the underlying data (e.g., image-to-image diffusion)Â (Saharia etÂ al., 2022; Liu etÂ al., 2023; Chung etÂ al., 2024). This latter approach is problem-specific; hence, it is not generalizable across inverse tasks.

3 Diffusion State-Guided Projected Gradient (DiffStateGrad)

We propose a Diffusion State-Guided Projected Gradient (DiffStateGrad) to solve general inverse problems. DiffStateGrad can be incorporated into a wide range of diffusion models to improve guidance-based diffusion models. Without loss of generality, we explain DiffStateGrad in the context of Latent-DPSÂ (Chung etÂ al., 2023) and note that DiffStateGrad applies to a wide range of pixel and latent diffusion-based inverse solvers (see SectionÂ 4).

The main contribution of this paper is to define this subspace so it results in better posterior sampling; in other words, to define a subspace such that when the measurement gradient is projected onto, the diffusion process is not disturbed and pushed away from the data manifold. We show in TableÂ 1 that indeed the subspace ğ’®tsubscriptğ’®ğ‘¡\mathcal{S}_{t}caligraphic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, defined by the intermediate diffusion state, results in an improved posterior sampling, unlike a subspace that is constructed based on a random matrix or the low-rank structure of the measurement gradient. Finally, we note that while DiffStateGrad can significantly improve the runtime and computational efficiency of diffusion frameworks that use Adam optimizers for data consistencyÂ (Song etÂ al., 2023a; Zhao etÂ al., 2024), the current implementation and this paper does not explore this aspect and, instead, focuses on the property of the proposed subspace.

Proposition 1.

The remainder of this section provides intuitions on how DiffStateGrad improves solving inverse problems in the presence of a suitable learned prior. Let the initial latent state ğ’›tsubscriptğ’›ğ‘¡{\bm{z}}_{t}bold_italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be on the manifold â„³tsubscriptâ„³ğ‘¡\mathcal{M}_{t}caligraphic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (e.g., being artifact-free, as the diffusion model is trained on clean data samples). We observe that pushing away from the manifold process (e.g., introducing artifacts) can only be introduced via the guidance by the data-consistency gradient step, as this is the sole mechanism by which information from the measurement process enters the latent space. Consider the manifold â„³â„³\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M of artifact-free latent representations. Each ğ’›tsubscriptğ’›ğ‘¡{\bm{z}}_{t}bold_italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT lies on this manifold, and the tangent space Tğ’›tâ¢â„³subscriptğ‘‡subscriptğ’›ğ‘¡â„³T_{{\bm{z}}_{t}}\mathcal{M}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M represents the directions of â€œallowableâ€ updates that maintain the artifact-free property staying on the current manifold.

Our DiffStateGrad method, through the projection operator ğ’«ğ’®tsubscriptğ’«subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡\mathcal{P}_{\mathcal{S}_{t}}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, approximates this tangent space. The effectiveness of DiffStateGrad depends on how well ğ’«ğ’®tsubscriptğ’«subscriptğ’®ğ‘¡\mathcal{P}_{\mathcal{S}_{t}}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT approximates the projection onto Tğ’›tâ¢â„³subscriptğ‘‡subscriptğ’›ğ‘¡â„³T_{{\bm{z}}_{t}}\mathcal{M}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_M. Hence, we discuss a rationale on how the approximated projection is sufficient for performance; we, accordingly, support this by experimental results inÂ SectionÂ 4. First, the SVD captures the principal directions of variation in ğ’›tsubscriptğ’›ğ‘¡{\bm{z}}_{t}bold_italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which are likely to align with the local structure of the manifold when the data is high-dimensional. Second, by adaptively choosing the rank based on a variance retention threshold, we ensure that the projection preserves the most significant state-related structural information while filtering out potential noise or artifact-inducing components from the measurement gradient. Finally, the low-rank nature of our approximation aligns with the assumption that the manifold of representations has a lower intrinsic dimensionality than the ambient space.

Hence, by projecting the measurement gradient onto this subspace defined by the current latent state ğ’›tsubscriptğ’›ğ‘¡{\bm{z}}_{t}bold_italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we effectively filter the directions orthogonal to the local manifold structure, and hence, remove artifacts-inducing components. This projection ensures that updates to ğ’›tsubscriptğ’›ğ‘¡{\bm{z}}_{t}bold_italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT remain closer to the manifold â„³â„³\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M than unprojected updates would, as stated inÂ PropositionÂ 1. Consequently, DiffStateGrad relies on the reliability of the learned prior and helps to provide high-probability posterior samples. This creates an inductive process: if ğ’›tsubscriptğ’›ğ‘¡{\bm{z}}_{t}bold_italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is artifact-free, and we only allow updates that align with its structure (i.e., updates that stay close to the manifold â„³â„³\mathcal{M}caligraphic_M), subsequent latent representation ğ’›tsubscriptğ’›ğ‘¡{\bm{z}}_{t}bold_italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT will likely be samples from the high-probability regions of the posterior.

FigureÂ 2 demonstrates the effectiveness of DiffStateGrad in removing artifacts when the MG step size is large; artifacts are introduced onto the measurement gradient and stay within the latent representation in PSLDÂ (Rout etÂ al., 2023). On the other hand, the reverse process via DiffStateGrad-PSLD (our method applied to PSLD) stays artifact-free, consistent with the mathematical analysis inÂ PropositionÂ 1 and the practical efficacy of the proposed SVD-based subspace projection. Finally, we note that the most significant improvements appear in challenging tasks such as phase retrieval, HDR, and inpainting. We attribute the effectiveness of DiffStateGrad, particularly in challenging tasks, to a reduced rate of failure cases (FigureÂ 3). By constraining solutions closer to the data manifold, DiffStateGrad minimizes extreme failures, enhances consistency in reconstruction quality, and improves overall performance metrics.

3.1 Efficiency

DiffStateGrad introduces minimal computational overhead. We perform SVD at most once per iteration, and for latent diffusion solvers, this occurs in the latent space on 64Ã—64646464\times 6464 Ã— 64 matrices. By selecting a low rank based on a variance threshold, subsequent projection and reconstruction operations are performed on reduced matrices, further decreasing computational complexity. FigureÂ 4 illustrates the runtime for the three diffusion-based methods of PSLDÂ (Rout etÂ al., 2023), ReSampleÂ (Song etÂ al., 2023a), and DAPSÂ (Zhang etÂ al., 2024) with and without DiffStateGrad. The figure shows that the additional computational cost of incorporating DiffStateGrad is marginal, typically adding only a few seconds to the total runtime (seeÂ SectionÂ C.2 for further details). We note that our method is not intended to improve efficiency, but rather to enhance performance and robustness.

4 Results

This section provides extensive experimental results on the effectiveness of DiffStateGrad employed in several methods for image-based inverse problems. We show that DiffStateGrad significantly improves (1) the robustness of diffusion-based methods to the choice of measurement gradient step size and measurement noise, and (2) the overall posterior sampling performance of diffusion.

4.1 Experimental Setup

We evaluate the performance of DiffStateGrad applied to three SOTA diffusion methods of PSLDÂ (Rout etÂ al., 2023), ReSampleÂ (Song etÂ al., 2023a), and DAPSÂ (Zhang etÂ al., 2024). These methods span both latent solvers (PSLD and ReSample) and pixel-based solvers (DAPS). We evaluate their performance based on key quantitative metrics, including LPIPS (Learned Perceptual Image Patch Similarity), PSNR (Peak Signal-to-Noise Ratio), and SSIM (Structural Similarity Index)Â (Wang etÂ al., 2004). We demonstrate the effectiveness of DiffStateGrad on two datasets: a) the FFHQ 256Ã—256256256256\times 256256 Ã— 256 validation datasetÂ (Karras etÂ al., 2021), and b) the ImageNet 256Ã—256256256256\times 256256 Ã— 256 validation datasetÂ (Deng etÂ al., 2009). For pixel-based experiments, we use (i) the pre-trained diffusion model from (Chung etÂ al., 2023) for the FFHQ dataset, and (ii) the pre-trained model from (Dhariwal & Nichol, 2021) for the ImageNet dataset. For latent diffusion experiments, we use (i) the unconditional LDM-VQ-4 model trained on FFHQÂ (Rombach etÂ al., 2022) for the FFHQ dataset, and (ii) the Stable Diffusion v1.5Â (Rombach etÂ al., 2022) model for the ImageNet dataset.

We consider both linear and nonlinear inverse problems for natural images. For evaluation, we sample a fixed set of 100100100100 images from the FFHQ and ImageNet validation sets. Images are normalized to the range [0,1]01[0,1][ 0 , 1 ]. We use the default settings for PSLD, ReSample, and DAPS for all experiments (seeÂ AppendixÂ C for more details).

For linear inverse problems, we consider (1) box inpainting, (2) random inpainting, (3) Gaussian deblur, (4) motion deblur, and (5) super-resolution. In the box inpainting task, a random 128Ã—128128128128\times 128128 Ã— 128 box is used, while the random inpainting task employs a 70%percent7070\%70 % random mask. Gaussian and motion deblurring tasks utilize kernels of size 61Ã—61616161\times 6161 Ã— 61, with standard deviations of 3.03.03.03.0 and 0.50.50.50.5, respectively. For super-resolution, images are downscaled by a factor of 4444 using a bicubic resizer. For nonlinear inverse problems, we consider (1) phase retrieval, (2) nonlinear deblur, and (3) high dynamic range (HDR). For phase retrieval, we use an oversampling rate of 2.0, and due to the instability and non-uniqueness of reconstruction, we adopt the strategy from DPS (Chung etÂ al., 2023) and DAPS (Zhang etÂ al., 2024), generating four separate reconstructions and reporting the best result. Like DAPS (Zhang etÂ al., 2024), we normalize the data to lie in the range [0, 1] before applying the discrete Fourier transform. For nonlinear deblur, we use the default setting from (Tran etÂ al., 2021). For HDR, we use a scale factor of 2. We note that PSLD is not designed to handle nonlinear inverse problems.

4.2 Robustness

FigureÂ 6 exhibits the sensitivity of PSLD to the choice of MG step size; the performance of PSLD significantly deteriorates when a relatively large MG step size is used, leading to poor results across all tasks. In contrast, DiffStateGrad-PSLD shows superior robustness, maintaining high performance over a wide range of MG step sizes. FigureÂ 7 demonstrates the robustness of DiffStateGrad methods compared to their non-DiffStateGrad counterparts when faced with increasing measurement noise. For both inpainting and Gaussian deblur tasks, the performance of DAPS and PSLD deteriorates significantly as noise levels rise. In contrast, DiffStateGrad-DAPS and DiffStateGrad-PSLD exhibit superior resilience across the range of noise levels tested.

4.3 Performance

We provide quantitative results in TablesÂ 2, 3, 4 andÂ 5, and qualitative results in FigureÂ 9. These results demonstrate the substantial improvement in the performance of DiffStateGrad-PSLD, DiffStateGrad-ReSample, and DiffStateGrad-DAPS against their respective SOTA counterparts across a wide variety of linear and nonlinear tasks on both FFHQ and ImageNet. For example, DiffStateGrad significantly improves performance and increases reconstruction consistency in both pixel-based and latent solvers for phase retrieval (TableÂ 4). We additionally show that DiffStateGrad does not impact the diversity of the posterior sampling (seeÂ FigureÂ 15). Finally, we note that DiffStateGrad is robust to the choice of subspace rank (FiguresÂ 10 andÂ 8). We refer the reader toÂ AppendixÂ B for the extensive qualitative performance of DiffStateGrad.

5 Conclusion

We introduce a Diffusion State-Guided Projected Gradient (DiffStateGrad) to enhance the performance and robustness of diffusion models in solving inverse problems. DiffStateGrad addresses the introduction of artifacts and deviations from the data manifold by constraining gradient updates to a subspace approximating the manifold. DiffStateGrad is versatile, applicable across various diffusion models and sampling algorithms, and includes an adaptive rank that dynamically adjusts to the gradientâ€™s complexity. Overall, DiffStateGrad reduces the need for excessive tuning of hyperparameters and significantly boosts performance for more challenging inverse problems.

We note that DiffStateGrad assumes that the learned prior is a relatively good prior for the task at hand. Since DiffStateGrad encourages the process to stay close to the manifold structure captured by the generative prior, it may introduce the priorâ€™s biases into image restoration tasks. Hence, DiffStateGrad may not be recommended for certain inverse problems such as black hole imagingÂ (Feng etÂ al., 2024).

6 Reproducibility Statement

To ensure the reproducibility of our results, we thoroughly detail the hyperparameters used in our experiments inÂ SectionÂ C.1. We also provide specific implementation and configuration details of all the baselines used inÂ SectionsÂ C.3, C.4 andÂ C.5. Moreover, we use easily accessible pre-trained diffusion models throughout our experiments. PSLD (https://github.com/LituRout/PSLD), ReSample (https://github.com/soominkwon/resample), and DAPS (https://github.com/zhangbingliang2019/DAPS) all have publicly available code. We will make the anonymous GitHub repository with our code available to the reviewers after the discussion forum opens.

Appendix C Implementation Details

C.1 Hyperparameters

For all main experiments across all three methods, we use the variance retention threshold Ï„=0.99ğœ0.99\tau=0.99italic_Ï„ = 0.99. For all experiments involving PSLD and DAPS, we perform the DiffStateGrad projection step every iteration (F=1ğ¹1F=1italic_F = 1). For all experiments involving ReSample, we perform the step every five iterations (F=5ğ¹5F=5italic_F = 5). See the sections dedicated to each method for further implementation details. We reiterate that various values of Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ are reasonable options for optimal performance (see FiguresÂ 10 andÂ 8).

C.2 Efficiency Experiment

We evaluate the computational overhead introduced by DiffStateGrad across three diffusion-based methods: PSLD, ReSample, and DAPS. We conduct these experiments on the box inpainting task using an NVIDIA GeForce RTX 4090 GPU with 24GB of VRAM. Each method is run with its default settings on a set of 100 images from FFHQ 256Ã—256256256256\times 256256 Ã— 256, and we measure the average runtime in seconds per image.

C.3 PSLD

Our DiffStateGrad-PSLD algorithm integrates the state-guided projected gradient directly into the PSLD update process. For each iteration (i.e., frequency F=1ğ¹1F=1italic_F = 1) of the main loop, after computing the standard PSLD update ğ’›tâˆ’1â€²subscriptsuperscriptğ’›â€²ğ‘¡1{\bm{z}}^{\prime}_{t-1}bold_italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we introduce our DiffStateGrad method. First, we calculate the full gradient ğ‘®tsubscriptğ‘®ğ‘¡\bm{G}_{t}bold_italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT according to PSLD, combining both the measurement consistency term and the fixed-point constraint. We then perform SVD on the current latent representation (or diffusion state) ğ’tsubscriptğ’ğ‘¡{\bm{Z}}_{t}bold_italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (ğ’›tsubscriptğ’›ğ‘¡{\bm{z}}_{t}bold_italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in image matrix form). Using the variance retention threshold Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„, we determine the appropriate rank for our projection. We construct projection matrices from the truncated singular vectors and use these to approximate the gradient. This approximated gradient ğ‘®tâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘®â€²ğ‘¡\bm{G}^{\prime}_{t}bold_italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is then used for the final update step, replacing the separate gradient updates in standard PSLD. This process is repeated at every iteration, allowing for adaptive, low-rank updates throughout the entire diffusion process.

For experiments, we use the official implementation of PSLD (Rout etÂ al., 2023) with default configurations.

C.4 ReSample

Our DiffStateGrad-ReSample algorithm integrates the state-guided projected gradient into the optimization process of ReSampleÂ (Song etÂ al., 2023a). We introduce two new hyperparameters: the variance retention threshold Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ and a frequency Fğ¹Fitalic_F for applying our DiffStateGrad step. During each ReSample step, we first perform SVD on the current latent representation (or diffusion state) ğ’tâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ’â€²ğ‘¡{\bm{Z}}^{\prime}_{t}bold_italic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (ğ’›tâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ’›â€²ğ‘¡{\bm{z}}^{\prime}_{t}bold_italic_z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in image matrix form). Note that we do not perform SVD within the gradient descent loop itself, meaning that we only perform SVD at most once per iteration of the sampling algorithm. We then determine the appropriate rank based on Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ and construct projection matrices. Then, within the gradient descent loop for solving ğ’›^0â¢(ğ’š)subscript^ğ’›0ğ’š\hat{{\bm{z}}}_{0}({\bm{y}})over^ start_ARG bold_italic_z end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_italic_y ), we approximate the gradient in the diffusion state subspace using our projection matrices every F=5ğ¹5F=5italic_F = 5 steps. On steps where DiffStateGrad is not applied, we use the standard gradient. This adaptive, periodic application of DiffStateGrad allows for a balance between the benefits of low-rank approximation and the potential need for full gradient information. The rest of the ReSample algorithm, including the stochastic resampling step, remains unchanged.

We note that the ReSample algorithm employs a two-stage approach for its hard data consistency step. Initially, it performs pixel-space optimization. This step is computationally efficient and produces smoother, albeit potentially blurrier, results with high-level semantic information. As the diffusion process approaches t=0ğ‘¡0t=0italic_t = 0, ReSample transitions to latent-space optimization to refine the image with finer details. Our DiffStateGrad method is specifically integrated into this latter, latent-space optimization stage. By applying DiffStateGrad to the latent optimization, we aim to mitigate the potential introduction of artifacts and off-manifold deviations that can occur due to the direct manipulation of latent variables. This application of DiffStateGrad allows us to benefit from the computational efficiency of initial pixel-space optimization while enhancing the robustness and quality of the final latent-space refinement. Importantly, DiffStateGrad is not applied during the pixel-space optimization phase, as this stage already tends to produce smoother results and is less prone to artifact introduction.

For experiments, we use the official implementation of ReSample (Song etÂ al., 2023a) with default configurations.

C.5 DAPS

We improve upon DAPS by incorporating a state-guided projected gradient. We introduce a variance retention threshold Ï„ğœ\tauitalic_Ï„ to determine the projection rank. For each noise level in the annealing loop, DAPS computes the initial estimate ğ’™^0(0)superscriptsubscript^ğ’™00\hat{{\bm{x}}}_{0}^{(0)}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT by solving the probability flow ODE using the score model ğ’”Î¸subscriptğ’”ğœƒ{\bm{s}}_{\theta}bold_italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Î¸ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Within the Langevin dynamics loop, we calculate the full gradient, combining both the prior term logâ¡pâ¢(ğ’™^0(j)|ğ’™ti)ğ‘conditionalsuperscriptsubscript^ğ’™0ğ‘—subscriptğ’™subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘–\log p(\hat{{\bm{x}}}_{0}^{(j)}|{\bm{x}}_{t_{i}})roman_log italic_p ( over^ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | bold_italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and the likelihood term logâ¡pâ¢(ğ’š|ğ’™^0(j))ğ‘conditionalğ’šsuperscriptsubscript^ğ’™0ğ‘—\log p({\bm{y}}|\hat{{\bm{x}}}_{0}^{(j)})roman_log italic_p ( bold_italic_y | over^ start_ARG bold_italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_j ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). For experiments, we use the official implementation of DAPS (Zhang etÂ al., 2024) with default configurations.
